pros: Good to work here in my opinion
cons: No cons to share at this time

pros: Most people were nice and cared a lot about the students and their success.
cons: My role was very dull. Poor manager at the time (who has since left and was replaced with someone much more competent).

pros: Colleagues are very good here. People work hard and the school culture and students are great.
cons: Financially the school relies upon tuition and has a small endowment. Faculty work really hard, teach full loads in addition to advising, serving on committees and providing service. Administration is disconnected from faculty and hasn’t created a shared mission.

job_title: Head Resident Assistant in Bristol, RI
pros: Positive improvements in the HRA role with new leadership team
cons: Communication could be improved between HRAs and central office staff

pros: The campus itself, the food, and the students' enthusiasm for the university
cons: Lack of planning and limited collaboration internally and between departments

job_title: Inclusive Excellence Program Coordinator in Bristol, RI
pros: RWU is working to create a diverse and inclusive place to work
cons: Not enough Diversity in leadership roles

job_title: Admissions Representative in South Bristol, NY
pros: nice campus, nice location as well
cons: Management in admissions office is close minded, narrow, not accepting of new ideas or change. Wastes employee’s time by not putting employees well being ahead of company/number goals. Does not like different; have to dress a certain way, have to abide by rules. Did not approve 1 day of vacation with over a months notice and gave no reason why. Not open or willing to help employees have a more flexible schedule (was told if you work overtime, you are never getting that time or money back in other ways). Just expected to work overtime with no benefit; no additional pay or time off to get that time back in your schedule. Can be working 14 days straight with no type of compensation for the over time. All in all, a terrible experience for employees who want to make positive change, who question authority, and who want a work-life balance. My colleagues were great and fun to work with. Management was disrespectful and rude, unwelcoming, and did nothing to try to improve or make the work environment more enjoyable.

pros: Easy work and set your own hours
cons: Low pay and paperwork process is annoying

review_title: Solid Place for Students to work
pros: Hours are very flexible and staff is easy to work with.
cons: Pay is poor and you have to work a lot of weekends

pros: Great experience Great professor Interesting work
cons: Small university with limited research resources when compared to larger scools

pros: Beautiful campus, Great coworkers, Pay average
cons: micro management through out campus

job_title: Information Services Specialist in Bristol, RI
pros: Entry Level, there were minimal responsibilities
cons: Pay was very low compared to other similar positions

pros: Great benefits, great environment, great campus
cons: Like every place there are bad apples, but overall, one of the best places to work in RI/MA.

review_title: Don’t pay enough for the abuse
pros: Great management and decent benefits. Flexible scheduling
cons: The supervisors are abusive and the pay is low. Not a very compassionate environment.

pros: Great benefits including tuition remission and tuition exchange
cons: Low wages but benefits balance it out

pros: Great location, unionized faculty, strong commitment to experiential education
cons: Becoming increasingly top-heavy with more upper administrative personnel and a turn towards a corporate rather than academic culture

pros: autonomy is good here for teaching
cons: low pay and low research support.

job_title: Assistant Director of Student Activities in Bristol, RI
pros: Great vacation and sick time, low health care costs and deductible, and retirement.
cons: Offices work in silos, not much opportunity to create change from lower positions

pros: Pretty campus, close to major metro areas.
cons: University has trouble competing. Scapegoating and finger pointing are abundant. Lets bad behavior go until it causes a problem.

pros: Everyone was professional, respectful, and friendly. From the students up to the dean, I felt they tried to keep everyone in communication.
cons: Financial Administration seems a bit off for a big organization. Adjuncts don't receive contracts until 2 weeks before school starts. We hear about budget shortcuts all the time. The most recent one, they had all the faculty and higher admin give up their salary to keep the school running.

pros: great location, great coworkers, great benefits.
cons: Senior management needs to listen to employees and become more flexible.

pros: nice people, good food, nice campus

job_title: Student Staff Assistant in Bristol, RI
pros: great staff, VP very nice, pretty easy job.
cons: work study job, stressful office during covid

job_title: Director of Public Relations in Providence, RI
pros: It has a good work-life balance

review_title: COULD be a Great Place to Work....
pros: Nice Campus, beautiful town, and good places to eat.
cons: Administration is NOT willing to support their employees, especially in athletics. The parents of the student athletes make all the decisions, not the coaches.

pros: I love my job. I am mainly writing this so I can do research on Glassdoor. They are making me create an account, so I am filling space writing this.
cons: There aren't any. RWU is really awesome.

pros: Wonderful location on the water, very near Providence.  Less than one hour to Boston, and Amtrak to NYC. Good pay, good benefits, heavy on study abroad opportunities for faculty. Very little shared office space, and you have good resources. Union shop. New President, new Provost, and a  fairly new slightly diverse board of trustees.
cons:
Union shop, run by few old timers who control most processes at the faculty level. Back-stabbing, active sabotage, and under-the-table-favors. Inconstancy in policies from administration, and very ineffective deans in most of the schools. Assistant Deans are over paid and apparently have nothing to do.  Other senior administration positions are entrenched with "RI politics" and are above the fray when their misdeeds find the light of day.

Significant growing pains. New President is not popular and New Provost just hired. The University is trying to find a niche, but the place is fragmented.

For every one producing faculty member there are five that sit back and do nothing, including not prepping for class. The school is expensive (45k a year) and caters to the massive amounts of helicopter parents, thus making grade inflation and "special allowance" done commonplace.

pros: Beautiful campus, many opportunities, good pay, decent benefits. Tenure process is vague, but since the place is a union shop, everyone gets tenure. Very little shared office space, professional development funds (about 3 thousand per faculty member), guaranteed raises.
cons: Tenure process is vague, but since the place is a union shop, everyone gets tenure. Most faculty members are mediocre at best, and those that rise above the rest are often sabotaged by other faculty members. RWU hires people who will not threaten the status quo, and Admin can't figure out why the faculty are generally lazy and unproductive. Very little diversity, but the administration is really focused on the issue, although their definition is  defined as people of color.  Basically RWU is looking for an identity and needs to find a way to be happy with what it is (whatever that is). Heavy teaching loads (4-3) and summer pay (overload) is low. The school has been sued several times (most recently for gender discrimination), and administration turns over frequently.  Admin has obvious disdain for faculty (not surprising since the few strong faculty members are over shadowed by the poor ones) and has a hard time changing the culture because the union fights change.

pros: RWU is managed by self-serving bureaucrats.  This may sound like sour grapes, but it isn't.  Senior staff are white, rich men who are completely disconnected from the challenges and problems on the ground staff and faculty face every day.  I can think of only one pro to write about this employer:  that in spite of moribund and toxic senior management, middle management and faculty somehow manage to keep the place going.
cons: No opportunity for middle managers, faculty, students, alumni or parents to have a real voice in addressing the genuine problems this institution faces.  Decisions are made behind closed doors by the men who are responsible for managing the institution.  These decisions, over and over again, do not reflect the very real problems staff and faculty face every day.  Doubtful the institution can prevail if this kind of senior management continues.

pros: The beautiful campus (even though parking is horrible).
cons: Unless you are a narcissistic, incompetent, sluggish white male you will not be valued at this institution. Worker bees do everything, while management and executives take all the credit and try to paint a picture of a functioning institution. They are in a horrible financial situation, which affects daily like and morale. Faculty gossip to students and run a muck, but cannot be touched because of their union contracts. Salaries are a JOKE with no rooms for advancement. Some faculty make 120K+, while 40hr/w staff make 50k. Office budgets are so tight they can barley order office supplies without the President signing off first. HR does not help or intervene when managers abuse their staff. People are leaving in droves, almost every department has vacancies - some without the ability to refill positions. Staff are overwork, underpaid, under appreciated, overlooked and generally abused by managers that should not even be allowed to interact with the rest of society. I am banking on the University College shutting down in the next few years and the school closing its doors not too long after - at least that is what the place deserves.  P.S. the diversity and inclusion content they push in the interview process is not real and will never be brought up again after you are on boarded-just saying.

review_title: Don’t let the beautiful campus fool you
pros: Colleagues who want to work together to best serve students. Collaboration is easy when egos don’t come into play.  The Student Affairs team is wonderful and caring.
cons: Where to start?  How about at the top. A disengaged President who is hanging on until retirement, which needs to come soon. Executives who are mostly all white men who have no clue about the value of diverse thought, which can best be delivered by people who don’t look like them. Terrible executives who are allowed to retire when they fire middle managers because they want to regardless of performance. RWU takes the “employee at will” to new heights. Work at RWU at your own peril.

review_title: Great staff, beautiful campus, lack of administration support
job_title: Assistant Direrctor, Career Services in Bristol, RI
pros: RWU has the best college food service and the most beautiful campus. There are wonderful faculty and very supportive staff members and an incredible number of majors.
cons: However, upper administration provided no recognition or support for staff. Salaries are not competitive and there is a lack of domestic diversity among the staff, faculty, and student body.

pros: Opportunity to pick your own hours, cool boss, satisfaction of creating great experiences for students, opportunity to learn various audio video or sound tech, great exercise
cons: Sometimes no work is available because hours are given on seniority basis (could be a pro if you have worked there 3+ years), work is primarily weekends and late nights (sometimes ending 12-2am)

pros: The campus culture is good, the benefits have been good and on campus food is great. Some events held on campus are open to the public and are generally all interesting.
cons: The location isn't ideal. Some of the leadership selection is questionable, the employee morale has decreased the past couple years do to leadership changes.

pros: I was very satisfied with the construction management major.  The teachers were very helpful and my peers were all good people and good group members.  Beautiful campus.
cons: Living on campus does not allow for any partying without being disciplined.  The police will break up any party they see or hear about in the town.

pros: Colleagues were wonderful, especially those outside of faculty ranks, in student affairs and academic affairs. Collaboration was easy. People care about the students and doing the best for the students.
cons: Horrible leadership (if you can call it that). Egos are HUGE and VPs and President care to only boost their stature at the expense of the staff and faculty. RWU practices fully that RI is an employment "at-will" state and has walked dozens of female employees, over a certain age, out the door and have kept underperforming white men. Years ago, the joke was that RWU stood for "Rich white underachievers" and administration attributed those terms to students. Now, those attributes clearly describe the school's leadership.

pros: The director of the tutoring department is really wonderful and makes you feel appreciated. Tutoring itself is a very rewarding job.
cons: Sometimes coworkers do not pick up the slack. For example, if a student walks into the writing center, the tutor at the front of the room often ends up tutoring them rather than students from the back offering to help.

review_title: Great Work-Life balance, civic engagement, and opportunities for practical experience for students
pros: Welcoming and collaborative company culture; outcomes-oriented while staying engaged personally with individual students, employees, and alumni; great faculty support in certain majors; and excellent executive and administrative support from the top down; allowance for departmental initiatives and creativity.
cons: Challenge to meet all outcomes expectations with available staff; student expectations about jobs, internships, and placements are not in line with the functions of outreach & engagement programs.

pros: Great university! The energy of the campus is great! I love working here!  Good benefits, especially the tuition related benefits. My particular department is very supportive of the need for work/life balance and allows flexibility when needed. I feel my work is valued. The campus itself is beautiful.
cons: Pay for staff is low. There is a lack of diversity. There is a distinct class system administration/faculty/staff.  Top down communication could be better.

review_title: Good people but lots of hours.
job_title: Coordinator of Residential Education in Bristol, RI
pros: Get to work with lots of very good people.  Job is satisfying at times.  Good job for someone that likes to work with college students.
cons: A lot of talk about work/life balance, but the demands on your time do not allow for it.  When you live at work, it can be hard to balance.

pros: The work is interesting.  No one is hovering over you to see if the work is done.
cons: Little direction awkward communication between departments.  Employees who have been there over ten years are resistant to change, un willing to orient new employees to the systems, and advocate a caste system that feeds their hostility to their peers.

pros: Easy to fit work study job into your schedule. You have a great deal of control over how many hours a week you work. Working for the university means you're serving your campus and peers. Typically, if you start working a work study job you can keep it year-to-year if you want to.
cons: Don't forget to swipe in and out!

pros: Decent pay, supportive administration within the department, excellent co-adjunct teachers.
cons: Didn't know if teaching until literally days before a semester were to start. Very low communication between full timers and adjunct. Generally low respect from full time faculty towards adjunct faculty.

pros: The experience of working as an academic tutor is not only extremely rewarding but helps my personal understanding of subject matter. Working with my peers in order to help them further understand their coursework is an extremely beneficial experience.
cons: I personally do not like how the timecard system functions. The system makes it difficult to change hours or correct mistakes in the system.

review_title: Roger Williams University is a bad place to work.
pros: The students are the only reason why this job is enjoyable.
cons: Management is terrible throughout the departments. Stuck in a union that protects the bad workers. Poor communication.

review_title: I wish someone had warned me...
pros: Campus is beautiful! By far the best part of working at RWU was the location. Students are engaged.
cons: Administration was horrible. This place has the opposite effect of a morale boost. Employees were not reward for hard work or taking on additional responsibilities. I started to job search almost immediately after starting to work here. No innovation in processes or thoughts. Organization is too top heavy.

pros: Overall this was a good experience with competitive pay. They tend to promote from within and have good management and administration.
cons: The company had a vertical structure that was not what I was looking for which led me to leave to company eventually.

pros: got to go onsite to see what we would be designing and where it would go.
cons: didn't feel like I learned much to prepare me for the future.

job_title: Senior Marketing Associate / Marketing Manager in Bristol, RI
pros: Great fun fast paced atmosphere where you can really connect with prospective students and co workers.
cons: Under staffed at times which resulted in lesser quality performances and services to prospective students and their families.

pros: They treat their adjuncts with tremendous respect and value our contribution.  The students are outstanding!
cons: While they pay more than some schools, the pay is still low.

pros: great location, great benefits, great coworkers, New President
cons: Current management style needs to change

pros: Real life industry exposure by managing a quarter million dollar equity fund.
cons: The time constraint affects the amount of sleep on a regular basis.

pros: Been teaching adjunct since 1999. Absolutely love it.  Autonomy, Great Students, Great Administration, Great union
cons: None that I have experienced

pros: Flexible hours, lots of down time, friendly managers, fairly easy tasks
cons: Not much advancement opportunity, low pay (min wage)

pros: It was fun and engaging
cons: There were no cons for me

job_title: IT Support Specialist in Providence, RI
pros: laid back work environment with flexible hours
cons: Small work space with no windows

job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Newport, RI
pros: Great staff and flexible hours
cons: Can sometimes be stressful and demanding

pros:
Beautiful location
Good food
Some nice people to work with
cons:
Upper management in constant political war
Frozen tuition didn't address rising costs to support business side of campus

pros: The ocean view, that's about it!
cons: They should be shut down!
